Who created the automaton Bell saw?

context: His father encouraged Bell's interest in speech and, in <a0_0>1863<a0_0/>, took his sons to see a unique automaton, developed by <a1_0>Sir Charles Wheatstone<a1_0/> based on the earlier work of Baron Wolfgang von Kempelen. The rudimentary "mechanical man" simulated a <a2_0>human voice<a2_0/>. Bell was fascinated by the machine and after he obtained a copy of von Kempelen's book, published in German, and had laboriously translated it, he and his older brother <a3_0>Melville<a3_0/> built their own automaton head. Their father, highly interested in their project, offered to pay for any supplies and spurred the boys on with the enticement of a "big prize" if they were successful. While his brother constructed the throat and larynx, Bell tackled the more difficult task of recreating a realistic <a4_0>skull<a4_0/>. His efforts resulted in a remarkably lifelike head that could "speak", albeit only a few words. The boys would carefully adjust the "lips" and when a bellows forced air through the windpipe, a very recognizable "Mama" ensued, to the delight of neighbors who came to see the Bell invention.
